Authors:
Antonia Carlucci, Francesco Lops, Maria Luisa Raimondo,
Francois Halleen, Lizel Mostert
Title:
Occurrence of black foot disease fungi of young grapevines
and nursery rootstock plants in Italy
Abstract:
Young grapevine plants from vineyards and nurseries that
showed decline and wood necrosis symptoms were collected from 2013 to
2015 in the Apulia and Molise regions, Italy. Isolations were prepared
from 45 diseased grapevine plants, and the fungal cultures were
identified. One hundred and eighty-two isolates resembling
Cylindrocarpon-like asexual morphs were identified through morphological
characterisation and DNA analysis of internal transcribed spacers 1 and
2 of the rRNA gene and the partial β-tubulin gene. Dactylonectria
torrensensis and Ilyonectria liriodendri were identified on the basis of
morphological features and the partial histone 3 gene, and are defined
as the causal agents of black foot disease on grapevine for the first
time in Italy. In addition, Thelonectria blackeriella is described as a
new species through morphological characterisation and a molecular study
based on multigenic analysis using sequence data for five loci (large
subunit RNA, internal transcribed spacers, β-tubulin, actin, RNA
polymerase II subunit 1). This new species was also associated with
black foot disease symptoms according to pathogenicity tests, with
representative isolates of each of these three species isolated.
Pathogenicity tests showed that all of these species can result in black
streaking in the wood of 1-year-old grapevine shoots. The identification
of D. torresensis, I. liriodendri and T. blackeriella from young
grapevine plants and rooted rootstock highlights the importance of black
foot disease in Italy, which has previously been overlooked.
